NOI.name: Net Operating Income
NOI.definition: NOI is the property's annual profit after operating expenses but before the mortgage and taxes. It's the core measure of operational performance and is used for cap rate valuation and lender coverage tests.
NOI.tooltipText: NOI is the property's annual profit after operating expenses but before the mortgage and taxes. It's the core measure of operational performance and is used for cap rate valuation and lender coverage tests.

CAP_RATE.name: Capitalization Rate
CAP_RATE.definition: Cap rate is NOI divided by property value — an unlevered yield implied by the current income and price. It's mainly a market comparison and valuation tool, not a full return metric.
CAP_RATE.tooltipText: Cap rate is NOI divided by property value — an unlevered yield implied by the current income and price. It's mainly a market comparison and valuation tool, not a full return metric.

CASH_FLOW.name: Cash Flow
CASH_FLOW.definition: Year-1 cash flow is the property's remaining pre-tax profit after operating expenses and debt payments are made. Positive cash flow generally means the deal can support itself day-to-day.
CASH_FLOW.tooltipText: Year-1 cash flow is the property's remaining pre-tax profit after operating expenses and debt payments are made. Positive cash flow generally means the deal can support itself day-to-day.
CASH_FLOW.note: This is pre-tax cash flow before reserves

COC_RETURN.name: Cash-on-Cash Return
COC_RETURN.definition: Cash-on-cash return is annual pre-tax cash flow ÷ total cash invested. It measures the first-year cash yield on your actual out-of-pocket investment and is heavily influenced by leverage.
COC_RETURN.formula: Annual Pre-Tax Cash Flow ÷ Total Cash Invested
COC_RETURN.tooltipText: Cash-on-cash return is annual pre-tax cash flow ÷ total cash invested. It measures the first-year cash yield on your actual out-of-pocket investment and is heavily influenced by leverage.

DSCR.name: Debt Service Coverage Ratio
DSCR.definition: DSCR is NOI ÷ annual debt service — how many times the property's operating income covers the mortgage payments. Higher DSCR means more cushion and generally lower lender/investor risk.
DSCR.tooltipText: DSCR is NOI ÷ annual debt service — how many times the property's operating income covers the mortgage payments. Higher DSCR means more cushion and generally lower lender/investor risk.

interpretation.below_1: Property doesn't generate enough to cover mortgage (red flag)

GRM.name: Gross Rent Multiplier
GRM.definition: GRM is price ÷ gross annual rent. It's a quick screening metric that ignores vacancy and expenses, so it's best used only for early comparisons.
GRM.tooltipText: GRM is price ÷ gross annual rent. It's a quick screening metric that ignores vacancy and expenses, so it's best used only for early comparisons.
GRM.note: Lower GRM = better value per rent dollar

IRR.name: Internal Rate of Return
IRR.definition: IRR is the annualized return rate that makes the investment's NPV equal zero, considering all cash flows and the sale. It's a time-weighted metric that's best read alongside equity multiple or NPV.
IRR.formula: Rate r where NPV = 0 = -Initial Investment + Σ(Cash Flow_t / (1 + r)^t) + Sale Proceeds / (1 + r)^n
includes: All cash flows over holding period
IRR.tooltipText: IRR is the annualized return rate that makes the investment's NPV equal zero, considering all cash flows and the sale. It's a time-weighted metric that's best read alongside equity multiple or NPV.
IRR.note: Best used with Equity Multiple to show both speed and magnitude of returns

NPV.name: Net Present Value
NPV.definition: NPV is the value today of all future cash flows discounted at your required return, minus the initial investment. Positive NPV means the deal is expected to outperform your hurdle rate.
NPV.formula: Σ(Cash Flow_t / (1 + discount_rate)^t) + Sale Proceeds / (1 + discount_rate)^n - Initial Investment
NPV.tooltipText: NPV is the value today of all future cash flows discounted at your required return, minus the initial investment. Positive NPV means the deal is expected to outperform your hurdle rate.
NPV.note: Heavily depends on chosen discount rate

EQUITY_MULTIPLE.name: Equity Multiple
EQUITY_MULTIPLE.definition: Equity multiple is total cash returned ÷ total equity invested. It shows overall cash profit but doesn't account for how long it takes — pair it with IRR for timing.
EQUITY_MULTIPLE.formula: Total Cash Returned ÷ Total Equity Invested
EQUITY_MULTIPLE.tooltipText: Equity multiple is total cash returned ÷ total equity invested. It shows overall cash profit but doesn't account for how long it takes — pair it with IRR for timing.

BREAK_EVEN_RATIO.name: Break-even Ratio
BREAK_EVEN_RATIO.definition: Break-even ratio is (operating expenses + debt service) ÷ gross operating income. Lower is safer because the property needs less income to cover all required payments.
BREAK_EVEN_RATIO.formula: (Operating Expenses + Debt Service) ÷ Gross Operating Income
BREAK_EVEN_RATIO.tooltipText: Break-even ratio is (operating expenses + debt service) ÷ gross operating income. Lower is safer because the property needs less income to cover all required payments.

DEAL_SCORE.name: Deal Score
DEAL_SCORE.definition: Deal Score is a weighted composite that summarizes multiple metrics (returns + safety) into a single 0–100 rating. Use it to compare deals quickly, then drill into the underlying KPIs to see what's driving the score.
DEAL_SCORE.formula: Weighted combination of CoC, IRR, DSCR, Cap Rate, and Equity Multiple based on investor profile
DEAL_SCORE.tooltipText: Deal Score is a weighted composite that summarizes multiple metrics (returns + safety) into a single 0–100 rating. Use it to compare deals quickly, then drill into the underlying KPIs to see what's driving the score.

ROE.name: Return on Equity
ROE.definition: ROE measures how efficiently the property's current equity is generating returns (often annual cash flow divided by current equity). It's useful for hold/sell decisions when equity has grown but cash flow hasn't.
ROE.formula: Annual Cash Flow ÷ Current Equity (or include appreciation + principal paydown)
ROE.tooltipText: ROE measures how efficiently the property's current equity is generating returns (often annual cash flow divided by current equity). It's useful for hold/sell decisions when equity has grown but cash flow hasn't.
ROE.note: Compare to alternative investment returns for hold/sell decisions
